definition:
Given the divisors $d_i$ of an integer $n$, if it is the case that for a
particular $d_i$ the equality $\gcd(d_i, \frac{n}{d_i}) = 1$ holds true,
then $d_i$ is called a [*unitary divisor*]{} of $n$. For example, the
unitary divisors of 120 are 1, 3, 5, 8, 15, 24, 40, 120 (while 2, 4, 6,
10, 12, 20, 30, 60 are proper divisors but not unitary divisors). All
the divisors of squarefree numbers are also unitary divisors.
